facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 160 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 160 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated October 30, 1958 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated October 30, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow

facts.text: High Court appeal was Criminal Appeal No. 105 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal No. 105 of 1957, arising out of the judgment and order dated February 12, 1957,

facts.text: Sessions Court judgment dated February 12, 1957 by Second Temporary Civil and Sessions Judge at Barabanki in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 102 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: of the Second Temporary Civil and Sessions Judge at Barabanki in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 102 of 1956. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent prosecuted before Judicial Magistrate, Barabanki for offences under cls. i and iii of s. 7 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was prosecuted before the Judicial Magistrate, Barabanki, for offences under cls. i  and  iii  of s. 7 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954,

facts.text: Offences were selling adulterated milk and selling milk without a licence.

anchor.surface_text: for selling adulterated milk and for selling milk without a licence. The learned Magistrate found that the offences had been proved

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate found offences proved and that respondent committed offences for the third time.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate found that the offences had been proved and further that, the respondent had companymitted the offences for the third time.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate committed respondent to Sessions Court under s. 347 CrPC due to sentencing limits under s.32 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Under the impression that his power as a Magistrate of the first class to impose sentence was limited by s.32 of the Code the learned Judicial Magistrate companymitted the respondent to stand his trial before the Court of Session, presumably acting under s. 347 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found respondent guilty of the offences.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was thereupon tried by a learned Sessions Judge of Barabanki who found him guilty of the offences with which he had been charged.

facts.text: Sessions Judge concluded offences were committed for the second time, not third.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge however came to the companyclusion that the offences had been companymitted by the respondent for the second time and number the third.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced respondent to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of two thousand rupees for each offence, concurrent, default six months further RI.

anchor.surface_text: He however companyvicted the respondent and awarded the minimum sentence prescribed by the Act for a second offence, namely, rigorous imprisonment for one year and a fine of rupees two thousand and, in default, rigorous imprisonment for a further period of six months for each of the offences and directed the sen- tences of imprisonment to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then appealed to the High Court at Allahabad.

facts.text: Mulla J of High Court held Sessions Judge had no jurisdiction due to s.21 of the Act, set aside conviction and remanded case.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon set aside the order of companyviction and the sentence passed against the respondent and remanded the case to the District Magistrate of Barabanki to be transferred by him to the Court of a companypetent Magistrate for trial and disposal.

facts.text: State appealed to Supreme Court against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The State has appealed to this Court against the judgment of Mulla, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Sarkar J on April 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number appear. 1960. April 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.--

facts.text: Respondent did not appear in Supreme Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the appellant. The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of Mulla, J., that the learned Sessions Judge had numberjurisdiction to try the case.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Magistrate was competent under s.21 of the Act to impose sentences exceeding s.32 CrPC limits.

anchor.surface_text: Mulla, J., who heard the appeal pointed out that the learned Judicial Magistrate had overlooked the Provisions of s. 21 of the Act which provides that numberwithstanding anything companytained in s. 32 of the Code it shall be lawful for a Magistrate of the first class to pass any sentence authorised by the Act in excess of his powers under s. 32 of the Code.

facts.text: Sessions Court had jurisdiction as case was committed by Magistrate having power to commit.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of a Court of Session depends upon the Code. It has jurisdiction to try any case which is companymitted to it. The case against the respondent had been companymitted to a Court of Session by a Magistrate having power to companymit.

issues.text: Whether the learned Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of Mulla, J., that the learned Sessions Judge had no jurisdiction to try the case. We do not think that s. 21 of the Act is a disabling provision. All that it does is to authorise a Magistrate of the first class to award a sentence beyond the limits prescribed for him under s. 32 of the Code.

issues.text: Whether s. 21 of the Act is a disabling provision

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that s. 21 of the Act is a disabling provision. All that it does is to authorise a Magistrate of the first class to award a sentence beyond the limits prescribed for him under s. 32 of the Code. It does not affect the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code, nor has it anything to do with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session.

issues.text: Whether s. 21 of the Act affects the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code or the jurisdiction of a Court of Session

anchor.surface_text: It does not affect the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code, nor has it anything to do with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session.

issues.text: Whether s. 21 makes commitment by a Magistrate competent to award the full sentence prescribed by the Act a nullity

anchor.surface_text: The section does not make commitment by a Magistrate competent to award the full sentence Prescribed by the Act, a nullity nor does the section interfere with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session to deal with a matter committed to it in spite of its provisions.

issues.text: Whether the Court of Session has jurisdiction to try any case committed to it by a Magistrate having power to commit

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of a Court of Session depends upon the Code. It has jurisdiction to try any case which is committed to it. The case against the respondent had been committed to a Court of Session by a Magistrate having power to commit.

issues.text: Whether a special provision in s. 21 of the Act for punishment by Magistrate irrespective of CrPC s. 32 amounts to abrogation of general law preventing application of s. 347 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Where a special Act has made a special provision for punishment to be awarded by a Magistrate irrespective of the limitations placed upon his powers under the Criminal Procedure Code, it amounts to an abrogation of the general law and the provisions of s. 347 of the Criminal Procedure Code cannot be applied to such a case.

holdings.text: The learned Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of Mulla, J., that the learned Sessions Judge had numberjurisdiction to try the case. We do number think that s. 21 of the Act is a disabling provision. All that it does is to authorise a Magistrate of the first class to award a sentence beyond the limits prescribed for him under s. 32 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court view that s.21 PFA disables commitment and affects Sessions jurisdiction; s.21 merely enables Magistrates to exceed CrPC s.32 limits

holdings.text: s. 21 of the Act is not a disabling provision

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that s. 21 of the Act is a disabling provision. All that it does is to authorise a Magistrate of the first class to award a sentence beyond the limits prescribed for him under s. 32 of the Code. It does number affect the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code, number has it anything to do with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21 only authorises exceeding sentencing limits under s.32 CrPC, does not prohibit or disable other procedural options like commitment

holdings.text: s. 21 of the Act does not affect the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code, nor has it anything to do with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session

anchor.surface_text: It does number affect the provisions of ss. 207 and 347 of the Code, number has it anything to do with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session. The section does number make companymitment by a Magistrate companypetent to award the full sentence Prescribed by the Act, a nullity number does the section interfere with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session to deal with a matter companymitted to it in spite of its provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21 is limited to empowering Magistrates on sentencing; no impact on commitment procedures under CrPC or Sessions jurisdiction

holdings.text: s. 21 does not make commitment by a Magistrate competent to award the full sentence a nullity nor interfere with Sessions jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The section does number make companymitment by a Magistrate companypetent to award the full sentence Prescribed by the Act, a nullity number does the section interfere with the jurisdiction of a Court of Session to deal with a matter companymitted to it in spite of its provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading: s.21 does not invalidate commitments or limit Sessions courts even where Magistrate is competent

holdings.text: A Court of Session has jurisdiction to try any case which is committed to it by a Magistrate having power to commit

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of a Court of Session depends upon the Code. It has jurisdiction to try any case which is companymitted to it. The case against the respondent had been companymitted to a Court of Session by a Magistrate having power to companymit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction derives from CrPC commitment by empowered Magistrate, independent of whether Magistrate could have tried the case

holdings.text: s. 21 does not take away the power of the Magistrate to commit, nor affect the jurisdiction of a Court of Session to try a case committed to it by a Magistrate empowered to do so

anchor.surface_text: We have said that s. 21 does number take away the power of the Magistrate if he has such power, to companymit, number affect the jurisdiction of a Court of Session to try a case companymitted to it by a Magistrate empowered to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects notion of abrogation of general CrPC provisions; s.21 enabling only, commitment remains valid option

holdings.text: A commitment is not void merely because the Magistrate was competent to try the case and not compelled to commit

anchor.surface_text: Further, the Magistrate did number lack territorial jurisdiction to companymit. It may be that the Magistrate was companypetent to try the case and award all punishments prescribed by law. It is also true that the Magistrate was number companypelled to companymit the case to a Court of Session. We are unable to subscribe to the view that a companymitment in such circumstances is itself void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate's competence or discretion does not invalidate exercise of commitment power under CrPC

holdings.text: The learned Sessions Judge had full jurisdiction to try the case against the respondent

anchor.surface_text: Therefore it seems to us that the learned Sessions Judge had full jurisdiction to try the case against the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative conclusion from statutory interpretation and CrPC jurisdiction rules applied to facts

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed and High Court order set aside
